questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Rett syndrome is a rare, genetic neuro developmental disorder.

Trofinetide is a synthetic analog of glycine-proline-glutamate, the N-terminal tripeptide of the insulin-like growth factor 1 protein and has demonstrated clinical benefit in phase 2 studies in Rett syndrome.

Reference: https://clinicaltrials.gov/study/NCT04181723

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for mood disorder, and he developed priapism. The causative drug is:
questions.solution:
Trazodone It is the first atypical antidepressant; less efficiently blocks 5-HT uptake, buthas prominent α -adrenergic and weak 5-HT2 antagonistic actions.

It is sedative but not anticholinergic, causing bradycardia rather than tachycardia. Nausea is felt, especially in the beginning.

Inappropriate, prolonged and painful penile erection (priapism). The α1 adrenergic blocking property has been held responsible for this effect as well as for postural hypotension. Trazodone used in depression associated with insomnia.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs is used for vancomycin dosing?
questions.solution:
Matzke Nomogram is used for Vancomycin dose adjustment.

Monitoring of antibiotic plasma concentrations also is important when using an extended- interval dosing regimen. For routine monitoring of extended-interval dosing, a single random concentration obtained 6 to 14 h after the start of the infusion can be obtained and plotted against a standard nomogram to determine if dosage adjustment is required.

However, the most accurate method for monitoring plasma levels for dose adjustment is to measure the concentration in two plasma samples drawn several hours apart (e.g., at 2 and 12 h after a dose). The clearance then can be calculated and the dose adjusted to achieve the desired target range.

Rumack Mathew nomogram is used for Paracetamol dose adjustment.

questions.text: Osimertinib is used in the NSCLC with mutation due to?
questions.solution:
Osimertinib is a third-generation, orally bioavailable, irreversible inhibitor of T790M-mutant EGFR

Osimertinib is also a very potent inhibitor of the EGFR mutants that are sensitive to first- and second-generation EGFR inhibitors. The T790M gatekeeper mutation in Exon 20 is often acquired after prior treatment with other EGFR kinase inhibitors.

choices.text: Nivolumab plus chemotherapy used in NSCLC
Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy used in NSCLC

questions.text: Which is true about the keynote 189 trial?
questions.solution: Keynote 189 trial is a famous trial on chemotherapy in patients of NSCLC using Pembrolizumab and Platinum based chemotherapy.

questions.text: Drug used for trastuzumab resistant Her-2 positive breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Lapatinib

This is a synthetic orally active inhibitor of EGFR/HER2 which penetrates cells and blocks tyrosine kinase activity of the liganded HER2 and thus interferes with signal transduction.

Lapatinib is indicated in metastatic HER2 positive breast cancer that is nonresponsive to trastuzumab and is used in combination with capecitabine.

Adverse effects are fatigue, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, decreased LVEF, heart failure and Q-T prolongation. However, lapatinib is considered to be less cardiotoxic than trastuzumab.

Option B: Vismodegib is a SHH(sonic hedgehog) protein inhibitor

Option C: Vemurafenib is a BRAF V600E inhibitor

Option D: Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A diabetic patient was started on a drug that decreased HbA1C from 7.6 to 6.8. She started complaining of itching around the vulvovaginal area. Which drug was she started on?
questions.solution:
This is a case of vulvovaginal candidiasis, a side effect of using SGLT2 inhibitors.

Dapagliflozin, Canagliflozin

These SGLT-2 inhibitors are approved for use in type 2 DM patients. After once daily dosing, they produce round-the-clock glucosuria and lower blood glucose levels.

Used alone or in combination with other antidiabetic drugs, they reduce HbA1C levels by 0.5-1.0%, but do not cause hypoglycemia.

The concerns which appear inbuilt due to their mechanism of action are-glycosuria which can predispose to urinary and genital infections, electrolyte imbalance, ketoacidosis and increased urinary frequency.

They are contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency.

choices.text: It is not absorbed in the stomach
It can cause fine tremors in therapeutic range

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding lithium?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Lithium

  • Nausea, vomiting and mild diarrhoea
  • Thirst and polyuria
  • Fine tremors may occur even at therapeutic concentrations.
  • CNS toxicity manifests as plasma concentration rises producing coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, hyperreflexia

Option A: Ethosuximide and Valproate are approved for Absence seizures, no Lithium

Option B: Lithium is administered via oral route and hence is absorbed via stomach

Option D: Lithium is teratogenic and causes Ebstein's Anomaly if taken in pregnancy

questions.text: A microorganism resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but sensitive to piperacillin clavulanate, cotrimoxazole? The causative organism is
questions.solution:
S. maltophilia Infections

The intrinsic resistance of S. maltophilia to most antibiotics renders infection difficult to treat.

The antibiotics to which it is most often susceptible are TMP-SMX, ticarcillin/clavulanate, levofloxacin, and tigecycline.

Consequently, a combination of TMP-SMX and ticarcillin/clavulanate is recommended for initial therapy pending susceptibility testing.

questions.text: Which of the following acts via the JAK-STAT pathway?
questions.solution:
Janus kinases (JAKs) are non-receptor tyrosine kinases involved in cytokine receptor signalling. Their interaction with STATs (signal transducers and activators of transcription) leads to activation of the transcription of genes involved in many vital events, such as inflammation, hematopoiesis, wound repair, and apoptosis, among others.

As a consequence, inhibition of this pathway offers current and potential treatments for myriad diseases, including dermatological conditions.

Dozens of growth factors and cytokines, including ILs, IFNs, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), erythropoietin, growth hormone, and leptin, interact with membrane receptors and initiate signaling via the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

Key Takeaway:

List of hormones acting via secondary messengers:

  1. G-protein coupled receptors(GPCR):
    • Gs: ACTH, CRH, TSH, GnRH, FSH, LH, Hcg, Vasopressin(V2), Catecholamines(beta receptors), Glucagon, Parathormone
    • Gi: Catecholamines(alpha 2 receptors), Acetylcholine(M2, M4 receptors), Somatostatin
    • Gq: Vasopressin(V1), Catecholamines(alpha 1 receptors), Gastrin, CCK, Oxytocin, Acetylcholine(M1,M3,M5)
    • Cgmp: ANP, NO
  2. Tyrosine Kinase receptors:
    • MAP Kinase: IGF, VEGF, EGF, FGF, PDGF
    • JAK STAT: Growth hormone, Erythropoietin, Insulin, Prolactin
